The Victorian Gambling and Casino Control Commission (VGCCC) is the statutory authority responsible for regulating gambling and casinos in the state of Victoria, Australia. Established in 2022, the VGCCC replaced the Victorian Commission for Gambling and Liquor Regulation (VCGLR) to provide enhanced oversight of casino operations, particularly following the findings of the Finkelstein Royal Commission.

== Establishment and Functions ==
The VGCCC was established in 2022 to strengthen regulatory oversight of gambling activities in Victoria. This move followed the recommendations of the Finkelstein Royal Commission, which highlighted the need for more stringent control and regulation of casino operations.

== Licensing and Regulation ==
The VGCCC is responsible for the licensing of gambling operators within Victoria. This includes the regulation of poker machines, ensuring compliance with legal standards, and overseeing the operations of Crown Melbourne, the state's largest casino.

== Casino Oversight ==
One of the VGCCC's primary roles is to oversee the operations of Crown Melbourne. This includes ensuring that the casino adheres to the regulatory framework and operates within the legal requirements set by the state.

== Minimum Return to Player (RTP) Requirements ==
The VGCCC enforces a minimum Return to Player (RTP) requirement of 87% for poker machines. This ensures that a fair percentage of the money wagered on these machines is returned to players over time.
